hook.text: A paralyzed man typed 90 characters per minute using only his thoughts and a brain implant.

buildup.text: Brain-computer interfaces read electrical signals from neurons and translate them into digital commands.

discovery.text: Current BCIs can control cursors, robotic arms, and even restore basic speech to locked-in patients.

twist.text: Companies like Neuralink aim to make BCIs mainstream, but surgery risks and ethical concerns remain huge.

climax.text: The technology promises to restore independence to millions with paralysis and neurological conditions.

punchline.text: Thought alone may soon control machines.

quiz.question: What can current brain-computer interfaces do?
options: Control cursors, robotic arms, and restore basic speech
Read and display a person's complete thoughts
Cure all forms of paralysis permanently
